awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Exploring Magnetic Communications for Challenging Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic Induction (MI) refers to the phenomenon where a current passed through a transmitter coil induces a current in a receiver coil that is separated by a short distance from the transmitter coil and is tuned to the same resonance frequency. MI can also be used to carry information by modulating the current. Unlike radio frequency (RF) communication, MI-based communication can provide several benefits such as low energy use, ability to work reliably in a variety of difficult propagation media (e.g., fresh/sea water, non-ferromagnetic metals, underground, etc.), and low leakage possibility because of fast decay of the signal with distance. Furthermore, since the MI technology is useful for efficient power transfer as well, it provides the possibility of passive tagging as well. MI technology is currently not well explored, and there are no commercial circuit boards that can be flexibly configured for experimentation. The primary purpose of this project is to develop relatively inexpensive MI-based transceiver boards and use them to explore the use of MI technology in several emerging applications, particularly those in the emerging smart infrastructure context.

The project will develop circuit boards for MI-based communications to support experimental research into this technology. The boards will provide flexible control of the operational frequency, coil size, and operating voltage. The project will experimentally explore the range, power consumption, robustness of the MI communications through a variety of media to enhance the understanding of the merits and limitations of the technology.  It will also explore the Multiple-Input, Multiple-Output (MIMO) capabilities in this setup for increasing data rates, and techniques to increase the range. By building several MI communications boards, the project will explore their use in several applications including on-line monitoring and tracking of fresh food supply chain, automated identification of MI tagged items in the smart shopping context and online monitoring of soil in the smart agriculture context. Each of these applications has a unique set of characteristics and requirements and thus can provide a comprehensive experimental evaluation of MI-based communications. The project will also enable other researchers to use our design and boards to further explore the MI technology for a variety of other smart infrastructure applications of societal importance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Much of the short-range wireless communications use the popular RF (radio frequency) based technologies, particularly the BlueTooth Low Energy (BLE). While BLE works very well in the air, it does not propagate well through media that contain water and the only way to make it work is by further increasing the power. In many applications such as monitoring of fresh-food during transportation or plant health monitoring, we need a technology that propagates well and consumes very low power, so that battery operated devices can operate for years without a battery change. For communications inside the human body, both the extreme energy efficiency and small size are crucial. Wireless communication is needed inside the body to manage chronic illnesses, which typically require collection of signals from multiple points to make an informed decision about the action, which may include control of amount/frequency of automated drug delivery, intensity/frequency of electrical shock, type of cortical stimulation, etc.

 

In this project we have explored magnetic induction (MI) communications and compared it with ultrasound (US) communications for such challenging environments, including the human body. Magnetic induction refers to magnetic coupling between two copper coils facing each other. The energy transfer in this mode of coupling is enhanced by creating a LC (coil + capacitor) circuit on each side that resonate at the same frequency, typically set to 13.56MHz. US communication refers to mechanical pressure waves between the transmitter and receiver and conversion from/to electrical signal on transmit/receive end. US communication generally ranges from a few hundred KHz to a few MHz range. The vibrating diaphragm becomes thinner and thinner at higher frequencies and thus mechanical integrity limits the upper frequency range. US is actually in use for intrabody communications, but generally for very short distances (a few cm at most).

 

Our research shows that both technologies work well in challenging media and show some surprising results. In particular, the experimental results showed that the behavior in reality is quite different than the one predicted by simple equations that are generally developed for homogeneous media such as air. In particular, the signal attenuation inside the body as a function of distance only goes down very gradually, rather than rapidly. This allows for both technologies to easily cover several 10’s of cm distance easily, thereby making them viable for many intrabody applications. For MI, it was also found that there is not much change in the received signal regardless of the relative orientation of the coils. Similar behavior was for the US transducers. This is vey helpful in real application as it implies that the orientations of the transmitter/receiver implants do not need to be controlled carefully. It was also found that the MI technology is quite robust with respect to the subject’s posture, movement, etc.

 

In terms of comparison between the two technologies, it was found that US actually works better than MI at lower frequencies where US transducers are easily available (up to 8 MHz). At higher frequencies (where US technology can only be investigated via simulations), we found that MI technology begins to overtake it a little about 10 MHz. We also found that the MI technology has a sweet spot around 20-25 MHz, where the attenuation is the lowest. Such a frequency range is quite appropriate for deployment, since at such frequencies the absorption by the tissue is not a concern.

Another significant result from the project is that our measurements tracked quite well with the simulation results obtained using the Sim4Life package that not only provides detailed simulation of electromagnetic propagation through the body, but also has very detailed human models. The package is however extremely compute intensive and very complex and required considerable effort to use. The results show that we can confidently explore intra-body communication using the simulation, something that is nearly impossible in reality.

 

Among the broader impacts, the key insight from this project is that MI communication is a viable technology for communication among implanted devices. This paves the way for its further exploration in the intrabody network context for various applications. Since battery replacement is largely impractical for implanted nodes, the same technology can be used for transferring power from outside (e.g., from a smartwatch like device worn on wrists or body parts) to the implanted nodes. This project paves the way for using MI technology for integrated communications and power transfer between on-body/in-body nodes and in-body nodes.
